item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Multi‐Component Domino Strategy for Regioselective Synthesis of Tetrahydrothiochromen‐5‐ones
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A silica‐supported sulfuric acid‐catalyzed three‐component domino strategy involving β‐ oxodithioesters, aromatic aldehydes and 1,3‐cyclohexanediones has been developed for the regioselective synthesis of tetrahydro‐5H‐thiochromen‐5‐ones under solvent‐free conditions. The reaction proceeded through the construction of two new C−C and one C−S bonds in a single step to afford high product yields.
Abstract A sustainable one‐pot multi‐component domino strategy for the regioselective synthesis of tetrahydrothiochromen‐5‐ones has been developed using inexpensive, stable, and recyclable silica‐supported sulfuric acid as the heterogeneous catalyst under solvent‐free conditions. This strategy enabled us to access a diverse range of valuable tetrahydrothiochromen‐5‐ones up to a 93 % yield via annulation of β‐oxodithioesters with aromatic aldehydes and 1,3‐cyclohexanediones. Furthermore, the catalyst was efficiently recovered, recycled, and reused for four cycles without a significant loss of catalytic activity, thus demonstrating the robustness of the devised methodology and its potential applicability in sustainable organic synthesis of the protocol.
item.content:encoded:
A silica-supported sulfuric acid-catalyzed three-component domino strategy involving β- oxodithioesters, aromatic aldehydes and 1,3-cyclohexanediones has been developed for the regioselective synthesis of tetrahydro-5H-thiochromen-5-ones under solvent-free conditions. The reaction proceeded through the construction of two new C−C and one C−S bonds in a single step to afford high product yields.


Abstract

A sustainable one-pot multi-component domino strategy for the regioselective synthesis of tetrahydrothiochromen-5-ones has been developed using inexpensive, stable, and recyclable silica-supported sulfuric acid as the heterogeneous catalyst under solvent-free conditions. This strategy enabled us to access a diverse range of valuable tetrahydrothiochromen-5-ones up to a 93 % yield via annulation of β-oxodithioesters with aromatic aldehydes and 1,3-cyclohexanediones. Furthermore, the catalyst was efficiently recovered, recycled, and reused for four cycles without a significant loss of catalytic activity, thus demonstrating the robustness of the devised methodology and its potential applicability in sustainable organic synthesis of the protocol.
item.dc:creator: Himani Gupta, Anil Kumar
item.dc:title: Multi‐Component Domino Strategy for Regioselective Synthesis of Tetrahydrothiochromen‐5‐ones

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Direct Coupling of Polyfluoroarenes with Acylsilanes Under Metal‐Free Conditions
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The direct coupling of polyfluoroarenes with acylsilanes in the presence of a catalytic amount of a strong base under exceptionally mild conditions has been realized. This reaction proceeds directly without the needs for photoirradiation and a metal catalyst, and features mild reaction conditions, a broad substrate scope, and significant potentials for preparing fluorinated bioactive molecules.
Abstract The installation of polyfluoroaryl group in functional molecules is of interest due to the presence of polyfluoroarenes in pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and advanced materials. Herein, we report the direct coupling of polyfluoroarenes with acylsilanes for synthesis of fluorinated benzylic alcohols in the presence of a catalytic base. This reaction could tolerate a wide range of polyfluoroarenes and polyfluoroheteroarenes, providing an efficient entry to fluoroarylated compounds. Deuteration experiments showed that the hydrogen source in the product was mainly from the polyfluoroarenes. The utility of this method was demonstrated by the derivatization of the product and the synthesis of a fluorinated analogue with antituberculous activity.
item.content:encoded:
The direct coupling of polyfluoroarenes with acylsilanes in the presence of a catalytic amount of a strong base under exceptionally mild conditions has been realized. This reaction proceeds directly without the needs for photoirradiation and a metal catalyst, and features mild reaction conditions, a broad substrate scope, and significant potentials for preparing fluorinated bioactive molecules.


Abstract

The installation of polyfluoroaryl group in functional molecules is of interest due to the presence of polyfluoroarenes in pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and advanced materials. Herein, we report the direct coupling of polyfluoroarenes with acylsilanes for synthesis of fluorinated benzylic alcohols in the presence of a catalytic base. This reaction could tolerate a wide range of polyfluoroarenes and polyfluoroheteroarenes, providing an efficient entry to fluoroarylated compounds. Deuteration experiments showed that the hydrogen source in the product was mainly from the polyfluoroarenes. The utility of this method was demonstrated by the derivatization of the product and the synthesis of a fluorinated analogue with antituberculous activity.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis of C2‐Silylated Indoles and Indolines Enabled by Iridium‐catalyzed Silylation of Indolines with Hydrosilanes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: We report an efficient iridium‐catalyzed one‐pot protocol for the synthesis of C2‐silylated indoles from indolines and hydrosilanes. Mechanistic investigations suggest that the transformation proceeds through a tandem dehydrogenation/C−H silylation pathway. Furthermore, an example of iridium‐catalyzed direct C2‐selective C(sp3)−H silylation of indolines is also disclosed.
item.content:encoded: We report an efficient iridium-catalyzed one-pot protocol for the synthesis of C2-silylated indoles from indolines and hydrosilanes. Mechanistic investigations suggest that the transformation proceeds through a tandem dehydrogenation/C−H silylation pathway. Furthermore, an example of iridium-catalyzed direct C2-selective C(sp3)−H silylation of indolines is also disclosed.
item.dc:creator: Lei Wang, Xinni Tang, Hui Sun, Wenjie Hu, Li-Wen Xu, Lei Yang
item.dc:title: Synthesis of C2‐Silylated Indoles and Indolines Enabled by Iridium‐catalyzed Silylation of Indolines with Hydrosilanes

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis of Heteroatom‐Containing Organic Molecules via Intramolecular Cross‐Dehydrogenative Coupling
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Heteroatom‐containing organic molecules hold a pivotal position in organic chemistry. Due to their extensive applications in pharmaceuticals and material science, the synthesis of these compounds under mild reaction conditions is highly significant. In this regard, intramolecular cross‐dehydrogenative coupling has emerged as a promising strategy in synthetic organic chemistry. This review summarizes the recent developments in the synthesis of biologically active heterocycles via intramolecular cross dehydrogenative coupling under transition‐metal free conditions.
Abstract Heterocyclic compounds or heterocycles constitute the most prominent class of organic chemistry. The extensive functional utility of these compounds in pharmaceuticals and material science has led to increased research interest in this area. Since heteroatom containing molecules hold a pivotal position in both chemistry and biology, a number of methodologies have already been known for their synthesis. However, advancement in the synthetic methodology for their construction under mild reaction conditions is highly important. In the current scenario of research, intramolecular cross‐dehydrogenative coupling has emerged as a promising strategy in the synthesis of complex organic molecules from simpler ones via direct C−H functionalization. This one‐pot atom‐economic protocol can construct fused heterocycles that are both pharmaceutically and medicinally important. The present review focuses on transition‐metal free synthesis of heteroatom containing organic molecules intramolecularly through carbon‐carbon (C−C) and carbon‐heteroatom (C−X) bond formation reactions reported over past one decade.
item.content:encoded:
Heteroatom-containing organic molecules hold a pivotal position in organic chemistry. Due to their extensive applications in pharmaceuticals and material science, the synthesis of these compounds under mild reaction conditions is highly significant. In this regard, intramolecular cross-dehydrogenative coupling has emerged as a promising strategy in synthetic organic chemistry. This review summarizes the recent developments in the synthesis of biologically active heterocycles via intramolecular cross dehydrogenative coupling under transition-metal free conditions.


Abstract

Heterocyclic compounds or heterocycles constitute the most prominent class of organic chemistry. The extensive functional utility of these compounds in pharmaceuticals and material science has led to increased research interest in this area. Since heteroatom containing molecules hold a pivotal position in both chemistry and biology, a number of methodologies have already been known for their synthesis. However, advancement in the synthetic methodology for their construction under mild reaction conditions is highly important. In the current scenario of research, intramolecular cross-dehydrogenative coupling has emerged as a promising strategy in the synthesis of complex organic molecules from simpler ones via direct C−H functionalization. This one-pot atom-economic protocol can construct fused heterocycles that are both pharmaceutically and medicinally important. The present review focuses on transition-metal free synthesis of heteroatom containing organic molecules intramolecularly through carbon-carbon (C−C) and carbon-heteroatom (C−X) bond formation reactions reported over past one decade.
item.dc:creator: Aanchal Batra, Manjot Kaur, Pushpinder Singh, Kamal Nain Singh
item.dc:title: Synthesis of Heteroatom‐Containing Organic Molecules via Intramolecular Cross‐Dehydrogenative Coupling

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Brønsted Acid‐Promoted Tandem Cyclization/Addition of Enaminones with H‐Phosphine Oxides for Synthesis of C2‐Phosphorylated 2,3‐2H‐Chromones
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: A facile and efficient protocol to synthesize C2‐phosphorylated 2,3‐2H‐chromones was discovered via Brønsted acid promoted tandem addition/cyclization of enaminones with H‐phosphine oxides. The reaction exhibited a broad scope, good functional group tolerance and good yields, and featured ability of a gram‐scaled synthesis. Results of mechanistic study revealed that the reaction initially undergone intramolecular cyclization to form chromone 5, which could subsequently be reacted with 2a to yield C2‐phosphorylated 2,3‐2H‐chromones through intermolecular addition
item.content:encoded: A facile and efficient protocol to synthesize C2-phosphorylated 2,3-2H-chromones was discovered via Brønsted acid promoted tandem addition/cyclization of enaminones with H-phosphine oxides. The reaction exhibited a broad scope, good functional group tolerance and good yields, and featured ability of a gram-scaled synthesis. Results of mechanistic study revealed that the reaction initially undergone intramolecular cyclization to form chromone 5, which could subsequently be reacted with 2a to yield C2-phosphorylated 2,3-2H-chromones through intermolecular addition

item.dc:title: Brønsted Acid‐Promoted Tandem Cyclization/Addition of Enaminones with H‐Phosphine Oxides for Synthesis of C2‐Phosphorylated 2,3‐2H‐Chromones

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Iodine‐Mediated Three‐Component Tandem Reaction for Synthesizing Indolo‐Fused 3‐Sulfenylpyrazolo[1,5‐a]pyrimidines
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A method for synthesizing indolo‐fused 3‐sulfenylpyrazolo[1,5‐a]pyrimidines has been developed through a one‐pot, iodine‐mediated domino reaction using indole‐3‐carbaldehydes, 3‐aminopyrazoles and dichalcogenides or thiophenols. Some products exhibit significant antitumor activity
Abstract A method for synthesizing indolo‐fused 3‐sulfenylpyrazolo[1,5‐a]pyrimidines has been developed through a one‐pot, iodine‐mediated domino reaction using indole‐3‐carbaldehydes, 3‐aminopyrazoles and dichalcogenides or thiophenols. Mechanistic studies suggest that the reaction proceeds through a radical pathway during the C−S bond formation, with an iodonium ion intermediate driving the cyclization step. Additionally, some products exhibit significant antitumor activity.
item.content:encoded:
A method for synthesizing indolo-fused 3-sulfenylpyrazolo[1,5-a]pyrimidines has been developed through a one-pot, iodine-mediated domino reaction using indole-3-carbaldehydes, 3-aminopyrazoles and dichalcogenides or thiophenols. Some products exhibit significant antitumor activity


Abstract

A method for synthesizing indolo-fused 3-sulfenylpyrazolo[1,5-a]pyrimidines has been developed through a one-pot, iodine-mediated domino reaction using indole-3-carbaldehydes, 3-aminopyrazoles and dichalcogenides or thiophenols. Mechanistic studies suggest that the reaction proceeds through a radical pathway during the C−S bond formation, with an iodonium ion intermediate driving the cyclization step. Additionally, some products exhibit significant antitumor activity.
item.dc:creator: Long‐Sheng Zhou, Ben‐Jun Han, Fan Teng, Xiang‐Wei Chang, Cheng‐Tao Feng
item.dc:title: Iodine‐Mediated Three‐Component Tandem Reaction for Synthesizing Indolo‐Fused 3‐Sulfenylpyrazolo[1,5‐a]pyrimidines

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis of β‐Aminoketones via Arylboronic Acid Catalyzed Decarboxylative Mannich Reactions of Enamines and β‐Ketoacids
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 11, March 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
An arylboronic acid‐catalyzed Mannich reaction between β‐keto acids and enamines was developed, yielding a series of β‐aminoketones in 48 % to 96 % yields under mild reaction conditions, with CO2 as the only by‐product.
Abstract Herein, we report an arylboronic acid‐catalyzed Mannich reaction of β‐ketoacids and enamines. In this transformation, the enamine served as an imine equivalent to react with the β‐ketoacids with the delivery of CO2 as the sole by‐product. A series of β‐aminoketones were obtained in yields of 48 % to 96 % under mild reaction conditions with 5 mol % catalyst loading. Additionally, the product was synthesized on a gram scale and further transformations were carried out. A possible catalytic cycle was proposed.
item.content:encoded:
An arylboronic acid-catalyzed Mannich reaction between β-keto acids and enamines was developed, yielding a series of β-aminoketones in 48 % to 96 % yields under mild reaction conditions, with CO2 as the only by-product.


Abstract

Herein, we report an arylboronic acid-catalyzed Mannich reaction of β-ketoacids and enamines. In this transformation, the enamine served as an imine equivalent to react with the β-ketoacids with the delivery of CO2 as the sole by-product. A series of β-aminoketones were obtained in yields of 48 % to 96 % under mild reaction conditions with 5 mol % catalyst loading. Additionally, the product was synthesized on a gram scale and further transformations were carried out. A possible catalytic cycle was proposed.
item.dc:creator: Beining Wang, Yiding Wang, Jun Li, Liuying Zhao, Junyu Wang, Xinyu Wei, Xiangyang Yuan, Haipeng Hu
item.dc:title: Synthesis of β‐Aminoketones via Arylboronic Acid Catalyzed Decarboxylative Mannich Reactions of Enamines and β‐Ketoacids

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Photoreduction Oxidation of Selenides with Isocyanides and Carboxylic Compounds: Access to Selenium‐Containing Imides
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 11, March 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A visible light‐driven photo oxidation‐reduction selenium amidation of selenides with isocyanides and carboxylic compounds for the synthesis of polysubstituted selenium‐containing Imides is reported. The reaction involves the functionalization of Se−Se bonds under mild conditions using a visible light photoredox catalysis, and has demonstrated a tolerance of various functionalization. A possible mechanism has been proposed.
Abstract A visible light‐driven photo oxidation‐reduction selenium amidation of selenides with isocyanides and carboxylic compounds for the synthesis of polysubstituted selenium‐containing imides is reported. The reaction involves the functionalization of Se−Se bonds under mild conditions by visible light photoredox catalysis with good tolerance of various functionalized group. A possible mechanism has been proposed.
item.content:encoded:
A visible light-driven photo oxidation-reduction selenium amidation of selenides with isocyanides and carboxylic compounds for the synthesis of polysubstituted selenium-containing Imides is reported. The reaction involves the functionalization of Se−Se bonds under mild conditions using a visible light photoredox catalysis, and has demonstrated a tolerance of various functionalization. A possible mechanism has been proposed.


Abstract

A visible light-driven photo oxidation-reduction selenium amidation of selenides with isocyanides and carboxylic compounds for the synthesis of polysubstituted selenium-containing imides is reported. The reaction involves the functionalization of Se−Se bonds under mild conditions by visible light photoredox catalysis with good tolerance of various functionalized group. A possible mechanism has been proposed.
item.dc:creator: Ding‐Yi Guo, Yan Deng, Xuan‐Lin Qin, Yan Pan, Yu‐Xuan Liu, Chong‐Hui Xu, Yan‐Xue Shang, Qing‐Wen Gui
item.dc:title: Photoreduction Oxidation of Selenides with Isocyanides and Carboxylic Compounds: Access to Selenium‐Containing Imides

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis of Vinyl Sulfones from Substituted Alkenes via Molybdooxaziridine Catalysis
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 11, March 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
This study presents the stereoselective synthesis of vinyl sulfones from styrenes through a novel atom transfer radical addition (ATRA) mechanism. The reaction works with complete trans‐alkene selectivity, high yields for substituted styrenes, and relies on sulfonylhydroxylamine as the NTs transfer reagent. This work provides a complete mechanism study for the proposed ATRA catalytic cycle.
Abstract Herein we report the MoO2Dipic promoted sulfonation of alkenes using N−Ts‐hydroxylamine as the quantitative source of Ts. The reaction works with high yields and stereoselectivities for styrenes with a wide variety of substitution patterns. A novel atom transfer radical addition mechanism involving the formation of molybdooxaziridine complex 1 as the active catalyst, difunctionalization with Ts‐NO, followed by oxidation, and then elimination as the rate‐determining‐step for the formation of vinylsulfone 3 has been proposed. Initial kinetic and mechanistic data indicates the formation of Ts‐NO and provides evidence for the proposed mechanism.
item.content:encoded:
This study presents the stereoselective synthesis of vinyl sulfones from styrenes through a novel atom transfer radical addition (ATRA) mechanism. The reaction works with complete trans-alkene selectivity, high yields for substituted styrenes, and relies on sulfonylhydroxylamine as the NTs transfer reagent. This work provides a complete mechanism study for the proposed ATRA catalytic cycle.


Abstract

Herein we report the MoO2Dipic promoted sulfonation of alkenes using N−Ts-hydroxylamine as the quantitative source of Ts. The reaction works with high yields and stereoselectivities for styrenes with a wide variety of substitution patterns. A novel atom transfer radical addition mechanism involving the formation of molybdooxaziridine complex 1 as the active catalyst, difunctionalization with Ts-NO, followed by oxidation, and then elimination as the rate-determining-step for the formation of vinylsulfone 3 has been proposed. Initial kinetic and mechanistic data indicates the formation of Ts-NO and provides evidence for the proposed mechanism.
item.dc:creator: Erin L. Doran, Jenna M. Doran, Ali A. Pinarci, Morgan E. Rossi, Rufai Madiu, Amari M. Howard, James L. Stroud, Dominic A. Rivera, Dylan A. Moskovitz, Alyssa N. Singer, Steven J. Finneran, Gustavo Moura‐Letts
item.dc:title: Synthesis of Vinyl Sulfones from Substituted Alkenes via Molybdooxaziridine Catalysis

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Solvent‐Directed Regioselective Cascade Reaction with Diazo Compounds
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 11, March 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A green, efficient and highly regioselective synthesis of pyrazoles and their derivatives from the combination of two different diazo compounds to afford N‐substituted using CF3CH2OTf as reaction medium was developed, without any catalysts.
Abstract A tandem system comprising cyclization reaction of diazo compound and cross‐coupling of the other one has been developed. This provides facile access to pyrazoles and there derivatives with high levels of regioselectivity in moderate to good yields. This process uniquely utilizes CF3CH2OTf both as a solvent and a catalyst under mild conditions. Mechanistic studies provide insights into the intricate sequence involved in the formation of pyrazoles and further selective cross‐coupling with another diazo compound.
item.content:encoded:
A green, efficient and highly regioselective synthesis of pyrazoles and their derivatives from the combination of two different diazo compounds to afford N-substituted using CF3CH2OTf as reaction medium was developed, without any catalysts.


Abstract

A tandem system comprising cyclization reaction of diazo compound and cross-coupling of the other one has been developed. This provides facile access to pyrazoles and there derivatives with high levels of regioselectivity in moderate to good yields. This process uniquely utilizes CF3CH2OTf both as a solvent and a catalyst under mild conditions. Mechanistic studies provide insights into the intricate sequence involved in the formation of pyrazoles and further selective cross-coupling with another diazo compound.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Releasing Intramolecular Stress of Curved Fused‐Core to Enhance N‐Type Carrier Transport Performance in A‐D‐A’‐D‐A Type Non‐Fused Small Molecule
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 11, March 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
We report a non‐fused small molecular organic semiconductor, IMIC, with an A−D‐A′‐D−A molecular type. Compared to fused A‐DA'D−A counterpart, IMIC features a simpler synthesis process, improved solubility, and a broader light absorption range. The non‐fused strategy alleviates intramolecular stress within fused ring molecules, significantly improving n‐type semiconductor property.
Abstract N‐type organic semiconductors based on non‐fused rings offer concise synthesis routes and low–cost production. Leveraging intramolecular non‐covalent interactions, non‐fused organic semiconductors can achieve fine regulation of molecular spatial configurations, thereby influencing the electrical performance. Herein, we successfully developed a non‐fused n‐type organic semiconductor with an A−D‐A′‐D−A structure, designated as IMIC. Compared to the fused A‐DA'D−A molecule, IMIC not only simplifies the synthetic steps but also significantly improves solubility and optical absorption properties. The non‐fused molecular architecture relieves the internal stress of rigid, curved polycyclic fused rings, granting greater spatial freedom to the components of the IMIC molecule, which is conducive to optimizing the spatial configuration of the molecule in the aggregated state. Ultimately, the electron mobility of OFET devices based on IMIC is tripled compared to TIIC, reaching 1.1×10−3 cm2 V−1 s−1 in ambient conditions.
item.content:encoded:
We report a non-fused small molecular organic semiconductor, IMIC, with an A−D-A′-D−A molecular type. Compared to fused A-DA'D−A counterpart, IMIC features a simpler synthesis process, improved solubility, and a broader light absorption range. The non-fused strategy alleviates intramolecular stress within fused ring molecules, significantly improving n-type semiconductor property.


Abstract

N-type organic semiconductors based on non-fused rings offer concise synthesis routes and low–cost production. Leveraging intramolecular non-covalent interactions, non-fused organic semiconductors can achieve fine regulation of molecular spatial configurations, thereby influencing the electrical performance. Herein, we successfully developed a non-fused n-type organic semiconductor with an A−D-A′-D−A structure, designated as IMIC. Compared to the fused A-DA'D−A molecule, IMIC not only simplifies the synthetic steps but also significantly improves solubility and optical absorption properties. The non-fused molecular architecture relieves the internal stress of rigid, curved polycyclic fused rings, granting greater spatial freedom to the components of the IMIC molecule, which is conducive to optimizing the spatial configuration of the molecule in the aggregated state. Ultimately, the electron mobility of OFET devices based on IMIC is tripled compared to TIIC, reaching 1.1×10−3 cm2 V−1 s−1 in ambient conditions.
item.dc:creator: Hua Sun, Wenju Li, Qin Zhou, Jing Zhang, Qichun Zhang
item.dc:title: Releasing Intramolecular Stress of Curved Fused‐Core to Enhance N‐Type Carrier Transport Performance in A‐D‐A’‐D‐A Type Non‐Fused Small Molecule

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: O−Doped Carbon Nitride: A Recyclable, Metal‐free Photocatalyst for Oxidative Amidation of Aromatic Aldehydes and Amines under Visible Light Irradiation
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 11, March 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A novel oxygen‐doped carbon nitride material was reported as an efficient solid photocatalyst for the synthesis of amide via the reaction of aromatic aldehydes with amines under visible light irradiation in the absence of metal, oxidant, or additives, and excellent functional group tolerance and good yields were observed. Additionally, this catalyst can also effectively activate the α‐position C−H bond of tetrahydrofuran and cumene.
Abstract Oxidative amidation of aldehydes with amines is a promising strategy for the synthesis of valuable amides. However, conventional methods often use toxic oxidants and additives, resulting in the generation of chemical waste. In this study, we report the catalytic oxidative amidation of aldehydes with amines using molecular oxygen under additive & metal‐free conditions in visible light, facilitated by an oxygen‐doped carbon nitride (OCN) catalyst. The OCN catalyst shows excellent activity in the production of various amides, demonstrating high functional group tolerance. Furthermore, the OCN catalyst can be reused several times without loss of activity.
item.content:encoded:
A novel oxygen-doped carbon nitride material was reported as an efficient solid photocatalyst for the synthesis of amide via the reaction of aromatic aldehydes with amines under visible light irradiation in the absence of metal, oxidant, or additives, and excellent functional group tolerance and good yields were observed. Additionally, this catalyst can also effectively activate the α-position C−H bond of tetrahydrofuran and cumene.


Abstract

Oxidative amidation of aldehydes with amines is a promising strategy for the synthesis of valuable amides. However, conventional methods often use toxic oxidants and additives, resulting in the generation of chemical waste. In this study, we report the catalytic oxidative amidation of aldehydes with amines using molecular oxygen under additive & metal-free conditions in visible light, facilitated by an oxygen-doped carbon nitride (OCN) catalyst. The OCN catalyst shows excellent activity in the production of various amides, demonstrating high functional group tolerance. Furthermore, the OCN catalyst can be reused several times without loss of activity.
item.dc:creator: Zezhao Huang, Hang Xu, Wenjie Zhang, Zeyao Liang, Ping Lin, Li Zhu, Xiaoquan Yao
item.dc:title: O−Doped Carbon Nitride: A Recyclable, Metal‐free Photocatalyst for Oxidative Amidation of Aromatic Aldehydes and Amines under Visible Light Irradiation

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Metal‐Free and Diastereoselective Synthesis of 4‐Oxa‐δ‐Lactams with 2‐Aza‐3‐Silyloxy‐1,3‐Butadienes and Fluoroalkyl Acylsilanes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 11, March 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A metal‐free and diastereoselective hetero‐Diels–Alder reaction for the synthesis of fluoroalkyl‐substituted 4‐oxa‐δ‐lactams with 2‐aza‐3‐silyloxy‐1,3‐butadienes and fluoroalkyl acylsilanes have been developed. The reaction can proceed smoothly even when exposed to air, and exhibits good substrate scope and high functional group tolerance.
Abstract Herein, we report a diastereoselective [4+2] cycloaddition reaction of 2‐aza‐3‐silyloxy‐1,3‐butadienes and fluoroalkyl acylsilanes for the synthesis of fluoroalkyl 4‐oxa‐δ‐lactams without a metal catalyst or an additive under open‐to‐air conditions. The reaction features mild conditions, high efficiency and excellent diastereoselectivity, exhibiting a broad substrate scope and good functional group tolerance.
item.content:encoded:
A metal-free and diastereoselective hetero-Diels–Alder reaction for the synthesis of fluoroalkyl-substituted 4-oxa-δ-lactams with 2-aza-3-silyloxy-1,3-butadienes and fluoroalkyl acylsilanes have been developed. The reaction can proceed smoothly even when exposed to air, and exhibits good substrate scope and high functional group tolerance.


Abstract

Herein, we report a diastereoselective [4+2] cycloaddition reaction of 2-aza-3-silyloxy-1,3-butadienes and fluoroalkyl acylsilanes for the synthesis of fluoroalkyl 4-oxa-δ-lactams without a metal catalyst or an additive under open-to-air conditions. The reaction features mild conditions, high efficiency and excellent diastereoselectivity, exhibiting a broad substrate scope and good functional group tolerance.
item.dc:creator: Dalu Song, Yunxiao Zhang, Xiaoqian He, Gang Zhou, Weilu Zhang, Xiao Shen
item.dc:title: Metal‐Free and Diastereoselective Synthesis of 4‐Oxa‐δ‐Lactams with 2‐Aza‐3‐Silyloxy‐1,3‐Butadienes and Fluoroalkyl Acylsilanes

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: An Operationally Simple, Regioselective, Platinum‐Catalyzed Hydroboration of Unactivated Alkynes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 11, March 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Herein we report a simple to perform, high yielding and selective hydroboration of unactivated alkynes using a commercially available catalyst system. The reaction is tolerant towards a wide range of use functional groups and provide (E)‐1,2‐vinyl boronate as the major product.
Abstract Herein is reported a new PtCl2/XPhos/Et3SiH‐catalyzed hydroboration method for unactivated terminal alkynes. Significantly, the reaction proceeds in hindered alkyne systems, and works well on acetylenes that contain multiple heteroatom‐groups to provide the desired (E)‐1,2‐vinyl boronates in reasonable to high yields with excellent levels of stereo‐ and regio‐control.
item.content:encoded:
Herein we report a simple to perform, high yielding and selective hydroboration of unactivated alkynes using a commercially available catalyst system. The reaction is tolerant towards a wide range of use functional groups and provide (E)-1,2-vinyl boronate as the major product.


Abstract

Herein is reported a new PtCl2/XPhos/Et3SiH-catalyzed hydroboration method for unactivated terminal alkynes. Significantly, the reaction proceeds in hindered alkyne systems, and works well on acetylenes that contain multiple heteroatom-groups to provide the desired (E)-1,2-vinyl boronates in reasonable to high yields with excellent levels of stereo- and regio-control.

item.title: Catalyst‐Free Visible Light‐Induced N−N Bond Cleavage for the Synthesis of Iminophosphorane Using Triarylphosphine and N‐Sulfonyl and N‐Acylaminopyridinium Salt
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 11, March 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Here, we report the radical coupling from PAr3 and N‐sulfonyl and N‐acylaminopyridinium salts via blue‐light‐induced Electron Donor‐Acceptor (EDA) complex without photocatalyst and transition‐metal. This method realizes the construction of minophosphorane through the cleavage of N−N bond, exhibiting broad substrate scope and good functional group tolerance.
Abstract Herein, we explore a visible light‐enabled radical addition for the construction of N‐sulfonyl and N‐acyliminophosphorane using triarylphosphine and N‐sulfonyl and N‐acylaminopyridinium salts in the absence of transition metal, photocatalyst, oxidant or base. This method employs PAr3 as both the reaction catalyst to promote the generation of amidyl radical via N−N bond cleavage of N‐sulfonyl and N‐acylaminopyridinium salts, and materials for the preparation of N‐sulfonyl and N‐acyliminophosphorane products. This transformation exhibits abroad substrate scope and good functional group compatibility.

This method realizes the construction of minophosphorane through the cleavage of N−N bond, exhibiting broad substrate scope and good functional group tolerance.


Abstract

Herein, we explore a visible light-enabled radical addition for the construction of N-sulfonyl and N-acyliminophosphorane using triarylphosphine and N-sulfonyl and N-acylaminopyridinium salts in the absence of transition metal, photocatalyst, oxidant or base. This method employs PAr3 as both the reaction catalyst to promote the generation of amidyl radical via N−N bond cleavage of N-sulfonyl and N-acylaminopyridinium salts, and materials for the preparation of N-sulfonyl and N-acyliminophosphorane products. This transformation exhibits abroad substrate scope and good functional group compatibility.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Mannitol‐Based CO Surrogate for Palladium‐Catalyzed Alkoxycarbonylation
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 11, March 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A new carbon monoxide surrogate with high CO loading based on the abundant and polyhydroxylated mannitol has been developed. Its efficacy was demonstrated in the palladium‐catalyzed alkoxycarbonylation of aryl bromides and a series of aromatic esters were produced in moderate to good yields with phenols as the nucleophiles.
Abstract Carbonylative transformation is already been accepted as a powerful toolbox in synthetic chemistry. However, the manipulation of toxic and smell‐less carbon monoxide gas lagged it from wide range applications. Hence the developing of new and efficient CO surrogates become an attractive topic. Herein, we developed a novel mannitol‐based carbon monoxide surrogate with an enhanced carbon monoxide loading capacity compared to known organic carbon monoxide surrogates. We successfully used it in the palladium‐catalyzed alkoxycarbonylation of aryl bromides with phenols only 0.5 equivalent of it required. This newly designed carbon monoxide surrogate offers additional possibility for further development in CO chemistry.
item.content:encoded:
A new carbon monoxide surrogate with high CO loading based on the abundant and polyhydroxylated mannitol has been developed. Its efficacy was demonstrated in the palladium-catalyzed alkoxycarbonylation of aryl bromides and a series of aromatic esters were produced in moderate to good yields with phenols as the nucleophiles.


Abstract

Carbonylative transformation is already been accepted as a powerful toolbox in synthetic chemistry. However, the manipulation of toxic and smell-less carbon monoxide gas lagged it from wide range applications. Hence the developing of new and efficient CO surrogates become an attractive topic. Herein, we developed a novel mannitol-based carbon monoxide surrogate with an enhanced carbon monoxide loading capacity compared to known organic carbon monoxide surrogates. We successfully used it in the palladium-catalyzed alkoxycarbonylation of aryl bromides with phenols only 0.5 equivalent of it required. This newly designed carbon monoxide surrogate offers additional possibility for further development in CO chemistry.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Improved Chemistry of myo‐Inositol: A New Synthetic Strategy to Protected 1‐Keto‐ and 1,2‐Keto‐Inososes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 11, March 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A refresh of the well‐known myo‐inositol chemistry is reported with a special focus on 2‐O‐alkylated compounds, chiro‐1‐inosose, 1,2‐diketone and 3‐deoxy‐1,2‐diketone derivatives optimizing the synthetic protocol also in gram scale. Orthogonally protected chiro‐1‐inosose was transformed into cyanohydrins to access to poly‐hydroxylated‐(aminomethyl)cyclohexane compounds.
Abstract A refresh and improvement of the well‐known myo‐inositol chemistry is reported here, setting up a new synthetic protocol to obtain orthogonally protected compounds, with a special focus on the preparation of 2‐O‐alkylated compounds. A gram scale synthesis of the 2‐allyl compound was performed and optimized in terms of yield. This intermediate is the precursor of chiro‐1‐inosose, for which synthetic procedures are lacking. Taking advantage of the easily handled allyl group, we were able to transform this keto compound into both the 1,2‐diketone and 3‐deoxy‐1,2‐diketone, intermediates of biological transformations used in several patented applications. Finally, to access poly‐hydroxylated‐(aminomethyl)cyclohexane compounds, the reaction of the keto compound with cyanide was optimized, affording cyanohydrins obtained as single stereoisomer, the precursor of the above compound.
item.content:encoded:
A refresh of the well-known myo-inositol chemistry is reported with a special focus on 2-O-alkylated compounds, chiro-1-inosose, 1,2-diketone and 3-deoxy-1,2-diketone derivatives optimizing the synthetic protocol also in gram scale. Orthogonally protected chiro-1-inosose was transformed into cyanohydrins to access to poly-hydroxylated-(aminomethyl)cyclohexane compounds.


Abstract

A refresh and improvement of the well-known myo-inositol chemistry is reported here, setting up a new synthetic protocol to obtain orthogonally protected compounds, with a special focus on the preparation of 2-O-alkylated compounds. A gram scale synthesis of the 2-allyl compound was performed and optimized in terms of yield. This intermediate is the precursor of chiro-1-inosose, for which synthetic procedures are lacking. Taking advantage of the easily handled allyl group, we were able to transform this keto compound into both the 1,2-diketone and 3-deoxy-1,2-diketone, intermediates of biological transformations used in several patented applications. Finally, to access poly-hydroxylated-(aminomethyl)cyclohexane compounds, the reaction of the keto compound with cyanide was optimized, affording cyanohydrins obtained as single stereoisomer, the precursor of the above compound.

item.title: Cardo Bisphenol Fluorene Fused with Dibenzo[g,p]chrysene for a High Refractive Index Monomer
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 11, March 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Synthesis of an unexplored cardo‐typed optical material showing a high refractive index of 1.83 is described. The hepta‐cycle precursor wherein dibenzo[g,p]chrysene and cyclopentanone are fused together undertook double arylation to form a quaternary carbon. The resulting cardo scaffold was ranked with the primal cardo‐monomer bis‐phenol fluorene in chemical properties, which clarified the efficacy of dibenzo[g,p]chrysene.
Abstract Synthesis and properties of a new cardo‐typed bis‐phenol are described. A dibenzo[g,p]chrysene (DBC) core that has one ester group at the bay was prepared, and then intramolecular Friedel‐Crafts acylation gave a key cyclopentanone intermediate. Finally, two‐fold arylation successfully yielded a DBC‐linked bis‐phenol. This new DBC‐linked bis‐phenol was compared with the prototype bis‐phenol fluorene (BPF). The structure‐activity relationship between these two bis‐phenols reveals that the expansion of the π‐conjugated system using a skeletal DBC influences the quality of its attributes with a refractive index of 1.83. This comparative study provides us a basis for future cardo structure material chemistry.
item.content:encoded:
Synthesis of an unexplored cardo-typed optical material showing a high refractive index of 1.83 is described. The hepta-cycle precursor wherein dibenzo[g,p]chrysene and cyclopentanone are fused together undertook double arylation to form a quaternary carbon. The resulting cardo scaffold was ranked with the primal cardo-monomer bis-phenol fluorene in chemical properties, which clarified the efficacy of dibenzo[g,p]chrysene.


Abstract

Synthesis and properties of a new cardo-typed bis-phenol are described. A dibenzo[g,p]chrysene (DBC) core that has one ester group at the bay was prepared, and then intramolecular Friedel-Crafts acylation gave a key cyclopentanone intermediate. Finally, two-fold arylation successfully yielded a DBC-linked bis-phenol. This new DBC-linked bis-phenol was compared with the prototype bis-phenol fluorene (BPF). The structure-activity relationship between these two bis-phenols reveals that the expansion of the π-conjugated system using a skeletal DBC influences the quality of its attributes with a refractive index of 1.83. This comparative study provides us a basis for future cardo structure material chemistry.

item.title: Front Cover: Cardo Bisphenol Fluorene Fused with Dibenzo[g,p]chrysene for a High Refractive Index Monomer (Eur. J. Org. Chem. 11/2025)
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 11, March 17, 2025.
item.dc:description: The Front Cover shows a cardo‐typed optical material with a high refractive index (1.83) that bends and focuses light. A heptacycle precursor from fused dibenzo[g,p]chrysene (DBC) and cyclopentanone underwent double arylation to yield a cardo scaffold comparable to bis‐phenol fluorene. A DBC core with a bay‐ester underwent intramolecular acylation and twofold arylation to afford a DBC‐linked bisphenol. Achieving a high refractive index with purely hydrocarbons supports future cardo material chemistry. More information can be found in the Research Article by T. Iwasawa and co‐workers (DOI: 10.1002/ejoc.202401409).

Achieving a high refractive index with purely hydrocarbons supports future cardo material chemistry. More information can be found in the Research Article by T. Iwasawa and co-workers (DOI: 10.1002/ejoc.202401409).

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Recent Advances in the Synthesis of Amino Acid Derivatives through Multicomponent Reactions
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 11, March 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
This review summarizes recent (2019–2025) advanced strategies in the syntheses of amino acid derivatives through multicomponent reactions, which is organized by grouping four types of catalytic strategies: transition metal catalysis, photoredox catalysis, organocatalysis and multi‐catalysis.
Abstract Amino acids play significant roles in the study of life sciences, pharmaceutical R&D, bioengineering, and so on. Artificial amino acid‐based drugs are important in advancing therapeutic innovation for multiple diseases including chronic pain, diabetes, and Alzheimer's disease. On the other hand, multicomponent reactions (MCRs) are demonstrated to be a powerful strategy for the construction of complicated structures from readily accessible starting reagents in one pot. Thus, applying multicomponent reactions to the preparation of amino acids and their derivatives can be a potent strategy for advancing the research of pharmaceutical chemistry. With the rapid development of various catalytic methods and multicomponent reactions, this review outlines recent construction methods of amino acid derivatives by transition metal‐catalyzed, light‐mediated and other organocatalytic multicomponent reactions.
item.content:encoded:
This review summarizes recent (2019–2025) advanced strategies in the syntheses of amino acid derivatives through multicomponent reactions, which is organized by grouping four types of catalytic strategies: transition metal catalysis, photoredox catalysis, organocatalysis and multi-catalysis.


Abstract

Amino acids play significant roles in the study of life sciences, pharmaceutical R&D, bioengineering, and so on. Artificial amino acid-based drugs are important in advancing therapeutic innovation for multiple diseases including chronic pain, diabetes, and Alzheimer's disease. On the other hand, multicomponent reactions (MCRs) are demonstrated to be a powerful strategy for the construction of complicated structures from readily accessible starting reagents in one pot. Thus, applying multicomponent reactions to the preparation of amino acids and their derivatives can be a potent strategy for advancing the research of pharmaceutical chemistry. With the rapid development of various catalytic methods and multicomponent reactions, this review outlines recent construction methods of amino acid derivatives by transition metal-catalyzed, light-mediated and other organocatalytic multicomponent reactions.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Earth‐abundant metal complexes as catalysts for the dehydrogenative coupling of hydrosilanes and alcohols
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: The dehydrogenative coupling of hydrosilanes with alcohols or water is a fundamental transformation in organosilicon chemistry, enabling the synthesis of alkoxysilanes, silanols, and siloxanes—key materials for coatings and adhesives. Traditionally, these reactions have relied on catalysts based on platinum‐group metals (PGMs), which are costly and scarce. The development of Earth‐abundant metal (EAM) catalysts offers a sustainable and cost‐effective alternative. This concept article highlights recent advancements in homogeneous EAM catalysis for these transformations, focusing on mechanistic insights, reactivity trends, and catalytic efficiencies. Catalysts based on manganese, iron, cobalt, copper, or zinc, are reshaping the field by offering efficient and selective processes for the synthesis of alkoxysilanes, silanols, and siloxanes. Moreover, a key feature of these catalytic systems is their ability to generate dihydrogen as a byproduct, offering potential applications in hydrogen storage and utilization. Despite the good performances of EAM catalysts in the hydrolysis or alcoholysis of silanes, challenges remain, including improving turnover numbers, substrate scope, and catalyst stability. Future developments integrating computational and experimental approaches will be key to optimizing these systems.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Mechanochemical Synthesis of 5‐Amino‐4‐Cyanoxazoles
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: A mechanochemical methodology for the preparation of 5‐amino‐4‐cyanoxazoles through the reaction of 2‐amido‐3,3‐dichloroacrylonitriles with primary or secondary aliphatic amines (or their respective salts) in the presence of dipotassium phosphate is reported. The process is carried out by processing the mixture of starting materials in a mixer mill, with ethanol used as a liquid‐assisted grinding (LAG) additive. Dipotassium phosphate serves as a cost‐efficient and non‐toxic inorganic base, ensuring 100% carbon economy of the process. The reaction produces the corresponding oxazole products with up to 97% yield in just 10 minutes. However, preparative scope of the method is restricted to highly nucleophilic and sterically unobstructed primary and secondary aliphatic amines. Aromatic amines display low reactivity at room temperature. For instance, indoline achieves only 43% conversion to its oxazole product after 3 hours.

The process is carried out by processing the mixture of starting materials in a mixer mill, with ethanol used as a liquid-assisted grinding (LAG) additive. Dipotassium phosphate serves as a cost-efficient and non-toxic inorganic base, ensuring 100% carbon economy of the process. The reaction produces the corresponding oxazole products with up to 97% yield in just 10 minutes. However, preparative scope of the method is restricted to highly nucleophilic and sterically unobstructed primary and secondary aliphatic amines. Aromatic amines display low reactivity at room temperature. For instance, indoline achieves only 43% conversion to its oxazole product after 3 hours.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis and Fluorescence Properties of Oxazolo[5,4‐b]quinolines: Exploring Structure‐Property Relationships and Design Strategies for Tailored Photophysical Characteristics
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: A series of oxazolo[5,4‐b]quinoline derivatives were synthesized via a two‐step process involving the reaction of 4‐trifluoroacetylazlactones with various substituted anilines, followed by intramolecular Friedel‐Crafts‐type cyclization and Robinson‐Gabriel oxazole formation. The systematic investigation of the photophysical properties of the synthesized compounds revealed that the position and nature of the substituents on the oxazolo[5,4‐b]quinoline core significantly influenced the absorption and emission characteristics. The 6,8‐dimethoxy substitution pattern was found to provide an optimal balance between high fluorescence quantum yield and moderate Stokes shift, whereas the 5,8‐dimethoxy substitution offered a unique combination of large Stokes shift and long wavelength emission. Additionally, the presence of a trifluoromethyl group at the C9 position was identified as a crucial structural feature for maintaining strong fluorescence. These structure‐property relationships provide valuable insights for the rational design of novel fluorescent oxazolo[5,4‐b]quinoline derivatives with tailored photophysical properties, which could find potential applications in the development of fluorescent probes and organic light‐emitting materials.
item.content:encoded: A series of oxazolo[5,4-b]quinoline derivatives were synthesized via a two-step process involving the reaction of 4-trifluoroacetylazlactones with various substituted anilines, followed by intramolecular Friedel-Crafts-type cyclization and Robinson-Gabriel oxazole formation. The systematic investigation of the photophysical properties of the synthesized compounds revealed that the position and nature of the substituents on the oxazolo[5,4-b]quinoline core significantly influenced the absorption and emission characteristics. The 6,8-dimethoxy substitution pattern was found to provide an optimal balance between high fluorescence quantum yield and moderate Stokes shift, whereas the 5,8-dimethoxy substitution offered a unique combination of large Stokes shift and long wavelength emission. Additionally, the presence of a trifluoromethyl group at the C9 position was identified as a crucial structural feature for maintaining strong fluorescence. These structure-property relationships provide valuable insights for the rational design of novel fluorescent oxazolo[5,4-b]quinoline derivatives with tailored photophysical properties, which could find potential applications in the development of fluorescent probes and organic light-emitting materials.

item.title: Reactions of Halogermylenes with NHCs: Selective Formation of Low Valent Ge(II) Species
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: The reactions of the Rind‐based 1,2‐dihalodigermenes, (Eind)BrGe=GeBr(Eind) (1a) and (EMind)ClGe=GeCl(EMind) (1b), with two types of N‐heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) (Im‐iPr2Me2 and Im‐Me4) resulted in the formation of the halogermylene mono‐NHC adducts, (Im‐iPr2Me2)(Eind)GeBr (2a') and (Im‐iPr2Me2)(EMind)GeCl (2b'), and the germyliumylidene cation bis‐NHC adducts, [(Im‐Me4)2(Eind)Ge]+[Br–] (3a) and [(Im‐Me4)2(EMind)Ge]+[Cl–] (3b). The resulting Ge(II) species are stabilized by the bulky Rind groups and the strongly σ‐donating NHC ligands, whose structures were confirmed by a single‐crystal X‐ray diffraction (SC‐XRD) analysis. Based on DFT and QTAIM calculations of 2a' and the cationic part of 3a, it was concluded that while the Ge–C(Eind) and Ge–C(NHC) bonds exhibit distinct differences in their degrees of polarization, all the Ge–C bonds display a partially polarized covalent character. Both reaction energy calculations and experimental studies suggested the potential liberation of an NHC ligand from the germyliumylidene cation bis‐NHC adducts, leading to the exchange of the NHC ligands. The formation mechanism of 3a from 1a and two NHC molecules via (Im‐Me4)(Eind)GeBr (2a) is discussed based on DFT calculations.

The resulting Ge(II) species are stabilized by the bulky Rind groups and the strongly σ-donating NHC ligands, whose structures were confirmed by a single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SC-XRD) analysis. item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Latent Ruthenium Complexes Supported by Two N‐Heterocyclic Carbene (NHC) Ligands, Synthesis and Catalytic Activity with Distinctive Activation
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Novel bis(NHC) ruthenium complexes of the form (NHC1)(NHC2)Ru(=CRR')Cl2 (where NHC represents N‐heterocyclic carbene ligands and CRR' denotes Ph‐indenylidene or benzylidene moieties) were prepared from second‐ and third‐generation Grubbs catalysts. These complexes exhibited thermal latency in ring‐closing metathesis (RCM), cross‐metathesis (CM), and several ring‐opening metathesis polymerization (ROMP) reactions. The species best activated by heat included either IPr or SIPr as an NHC ligand, highlighting how bulky isopropyl substituents enhance NHC lability. Most interestingly, UV‐C (255 nm) irradiation readily activated two complexes that contained benzylidene ligands for the ROMP of cyclooctadiene, providing a unique opportunity for the efficient UV‐C activation of olefin metathesis catalysts. Beyond their special utility in UV‐C‐initiated ROMP, because of their high robustness, these complexes showed promising activity for challenging high‐temperature CM and RCM reactions of alkenyl‐nitrile substrates.
item.content:encoded: Novel bis(NHC) ruthenium complexes of the form (NHC1)(NHC2)Ru(=CRR')Cl2 (where NHC represents N-heterocyclic carbene ligands and CRR' denotes Ph-indenylidene or benzylidene moieties) were prepared from second- and third-generation Grubbs catalysts. These complexes exhibited thermal latency in ring-closing metathesis (RCM), cross-metathesis (CM), and several ring-opening metathesis polymerization (ROMP) reactions.  The species best activated by heat included either IPr or SIPr as an NHC ligand, highlighting how bulky isopropyl substituents enhance NHC lability. Most interestingly, UV-C (255 nm) irradiation readily activated two complexes that contained benzylidene ligands for the ROMP of cyclooctadiene, providing a unique opportunity for the efficient UV-C activation of olefin metathesis catalysts. Beyond their special utility in UV-C-initiated ROMP, because of their high robustness, these complexes showed promising activity for challenging high-temperature CM and RCM reactions of alkenyl-nitrile substrates.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Visible‐Light‐Induced Three‐Component Radical Strategy for the Synthesis of β‐Amino Alcohols
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: This study presents a visible‐light‐mediated three‐component radical reaction involving alcohols or alkanes and in situ‐formed imines. The imines, generated from aldehydes and amines, serve as key reactants, while the inexpensive and readily available sodium decatungstate (NaDT) is employed as a photocatalyst. This strategy enables the functionalization of industrially accessible alcohols or alkanes to synthesize β‐amino alcohols via an intermolecular hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) mechanism under visible‐light irradiation. The reaction is operationally simple, exhibits high conversion efficiency, facilitates straightforward post‐reaction processing, and demonstrates excellent atom and step economy.
item.content:encoded: This study presents a visible-light-mediated three-component radical reaction involving alcohols or alkanes and in situ-formed imines. The imines, generated from aldehydes and amines, serve as key reactants, while the inexpensive and readily available sodium decatungstate (NaDT) is employed as a photocatalyst. This strategy enables the functionalization of industrially accessible alcohols or alkanes to synthesize β-amino alcohols via an intermolecular hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) mechanism under visible-light irradiation. The reaction is operationally simple, exhibits high conversion efficiency, facilitates straightforward post-reaction processing, and demonstrates excellent atom and step economy.

item.dc:title: Visible‐Light‐Induced Three‐Component Radical Strategy for the Synthesis of β‐Amino Alcohols

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Regioselective Hydroformylation of α,β‐Unsaturated Esters: Impact of Reaction Parameters & Reaction Optimization
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The hydroformylation of methyl 4‐chlorocinnamate exhibited either high values for regioselectivity (96 %) or selectivity (78 %) for the β‐aldehyde 2 a depending on pressure, CO/H2 composition and temperature in a design of experiments approach. Expanding the substrate scope gave insights into the structure‐activity relationship revealing a significant electronic influence of the substituent on regioselectivity and selectivity for the β‐aldehyde.
Abstract The hydroformylation of α,β‐unsaturated esters represents a highly atom‐economical route towards β‐aldehydes with potential application as precursors for derivatization to pharmaceuticals such as (R)‐Baclofen or Pregabalin. Methyl 4‐chlorocinnamate as an α,β‐unsaturated ester has been rarely studied in hydroformylation, particularly with regard to a parameter screening for reaction optimization. In this work, regioselective hydroformylation of methyl 4‐chlorocinnamate to the desired β‐aldehyde utilizing a phosphine‐free Rh catalyst was investigated with a focus on identification of parameters with a significant effect on regioselectivity and selectivity to the β‐aldehyde amongst all products. Initially, reaction time, solvent, and catalyst loading were screened, followed by a reaction optimization using design of experiments (DoE). The reaction output was analyzed in relation to pressure, temperature and CO/H2 composition revealing that while either regioselectivity or overall selectivity (termed selectivity) can attain high values, none of the conditions leads to optimal levels of both regioselectivity and selectivity. As predicted by the model, the experimental results under two different conditions demonstrated excellent regioselectivity (96 %) with medium selectivity (57 %) and high selectivity (78 %) with good regioselectivity (93 %). Expansion of the substrate scope to substituted methyl cinnamate derivatives showed significant influence of the substituents and, thus, their electronic effects on regioselectivity and selectivity.
item.content:encoded:

Expanding the substrate scope gave insights into the structure-activity relationship revealing a significant electronic influence of the substituent on regioselectivity and selectivity for the β-aldehyde.


Abstract

The hydroformylation of α,β-unsaturated esters represents a highly atom-economical route towards β-aldehydes with potential application as precursors for derivatization to pharmaceuticals such as (R)-Baclofen or Pregabalin. Methyl 4-chlorocinnamate as an α,β-unsaturated ester has been rarely studied in hydroformylation, particularly with regard to a parameter screening for reaction optimization. In this work, regioselective hydroformylation of methyl 4-chlorocinnamate to the desired β-aldehyde utilizing a phosphine-free Rh catalyst was investigated with a focus on identification of parameters with a significant effect on regioselectivity and selectivity to the β-aldehyde amongst all products. Initially, reaction time, solvent, and catalyst loading were screened, followed by a reaction optimization using design of experiments (DoE). The reaction output was analyzed in relation to pressure, temperature and CO/H2 composition revealing that while either regioselectivity or overall selectivity (termed selectivity) can attain high values, none of the conditions leads to optimal levels of both regioselectivity and selectivity. As predicted by the model, the experimental results under two different conditions demonstrated excellent regioselectivity (96 %) with medium selectivity (57 %) and high selectivity (78 %) with good regioselectivity (93 %). Expansion of the substrate scope to substituted methyl cinnamate derivatives showed significant influence of the substituents and, thus, their electronic effects on regioselectivity and selectivity.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: An Approach to Functionalization of Cucurbit[n]uril Through a Tetrahydrothiopheno Equatorial Substituent
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The inclusion of a tetrahydrothiopheno equatorial substituent on a glycoluril moiety of a cucurbit[n]uril provides an avenue to reactive derivatization. This process extends the potential for future applications of the cucurbituril homologues 7 and 8. Also highlighted are new glycoluril derivatives that may serve as precursors in the synthesis of cucurbit[n]uril or their analogues.
Abstract A tetrahydrothiopheno equatorial substituent on a glycoluril moiety of a cucurbit[n]uril was found to be robust and provided a capacity for reactive derivatization. We have demonstrated this on tetrahydrothiopheno substituted glycoluril derivatives as a proof of concept, then translatable reactions were applied to tetrahydrothiopheno substituted cucurbituril homologues 7 and 8. In addition to the successful derivatization tetrahydrothiophenocucurbit[7 and 8]uril, some new glycoluril derivatives have been synthesized, which may serve as future precursors for the synthesis of other substituted cucurbit[n]uril and their analogues.

Also highlighted are new glycoluril derivatives that may serve as precursors in the synthesis of cucurbit[n]uril or their analogues.


Abstract

A tetrahydrothiopheno equatorial substituent on a glycoluril moiety of a cucurbit[n]uril was found to be robust and provided a capacity for reactive derivatization. We have demonstrated this on tetrahydrothiopheno substituted glycoluril derivatives as a proof of concept, then translatable reactions were applied to tetrahydrothiopheno substituted cucurbituril homologues 7 and 8. In addition to the successful derivatization tetrahydrothiophenocucurbit[7 and 8]uril, some new glycoluril derivatives have been synthesized, which may serve as future precursors for the synthesis of other substituted cucurbit[n]uril and their analogues.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Rhodium‐Catalyzed Cascade Carbene Coupling Reactions of α,α‐Difluoro‐N‐Tosylhydrazones, Arylboronates and Alcohols for the Synthesis of Alkyl Enol Ethers
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A rhodium‐catalyzed three‐component carbene coupling reaction of α,α‐difluoro‐N‐tosylhydrazones, arylboronates and alcohols for the synthesis of alkyl enol ethers is disclosed. This reaction not only expands the application scope of α,α‐difluoro‐N‐tosylhydrazones in cascade carbene coupling reactions, but also provides an alternative synthetic method for alkyl enol ethers.
Abstract Transition metal‐catalyzed cascade carbene coupling reactions are highly valued strategies for the assembly of complex molecules. Among various carbene precursors, α,α‐difluoro‐N‐tosylhydrazones have emerged as promising candidates in such reactions. In this study, we report a rhodium‐catalyzed three‐component carbene coupling reaction involving α,α‐difluoro‐N‐tosylhydrazones, arylboronates and alcohols. This approach provides a complementary method for the efficient synthesis of alkyl enol ethers, showcasing a broad substrate scope and favorable yields. Additionally, the subsequent transformations of the resulting products demonstrate the synthetic utility and versatility of this protocol.
item.content:encoded:

This reaction not only expands the application scope of α,α-difluoro-N-tosylhydrazones in cascade carbene coupling reactions, but also provides an alternative synthetic method for alkyl enol ethers.


Abstract

Transition metal-catalyzed cascade carbene coupling reactions are highly valued strategies for the assembly of complex molecules. Among various carbene precursors, α,α-difluoro-N-tosylhydrazones have emerged as promising candidates in such reactions. In this study, we report a rhodium-catalyzed three-component carbene coupling reaction involving α,α-difluoro-N-tosylhydrazones, arylboronates and alcohols. This approach provides a complementary method for the efficient synthesis of alkyl enol ethers, showcasing a broad substrate scope and favorable yields. Additionally, the subsequent transformations of the resulting products demonstrate the synthetic utility and versatility of this protocol.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: NHC‐Organocatalyzed Multicomponent Fluorination and Fluoroalkylation for Access to Fluorine‐Containing Compounds
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
This minireview systematically summarizes the recent advancements in N‐heterocyclic carbene (NHC)‐catalyzed multicomponent reactions (MCRs) for the synthesis of fluorine‐containing compounds. Key developments in NHC‐catalyzed electrophilic fluorination, trifluoromethylation, and radical fluoroalkylation are explored, with emphasis on functional group compatibility and mechanistic insights. Meanwhile, the review provides perspectives on the challenges in the field and aims to expand the research direction of fluorine chemistry.
Abstract Fluorine‐containing compounds have garnered significant attention in organic synthesis, pharmaceuticals, and agrochemicals. The development of efficient methods for constructing fluorinated structures has become a critical topic in organic synthesis. Additionally, N‐heterocyclic carbene (NHC)‐organocatalyzed multicomponent fluorination and fluoroalkylation have emerged as a powerful strategy for accessing diverse fluorinated compounds. The minireview summarizes the construction of fluorine‐containing compounds via NHC‐organocatalyzed multicomponent reactions over the past 15 years. Key reaction types include: i) NHC‐catalyzed electrophilic fluorination and trifluoromethylation; and ii) NHC‐catalyzed radical fluoroalkylation and cooperative NHC / transition metal catalyzed radical fluoroalkylation. Perspectives and insights into recent advancements in the research field are also provided at the end of the review.
item.content:encoded:
This minireview systematically summarizes the recent advancements in N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC)-catalyzed multicomponent reactions (MCRs) for the synthesis of fluorine-containing compounds. Key developments in NHC-catalyzed electrophilic fluorination, trifluoromethylation, and radical fluoroalkylation are explored, with emphasis on functional group compatibility and mechanistic insights. Meanwhile, the review provides perspectives on the challenges in the field and aims to expand the research direction of fluorine chemistry.


Abstract

Fluorine-containing compounds have garnered significant attention in organic synthesis, pharmaceuticals, and agrochemicals. The development of efficient methods for constructing fluorinated structures has become a critical topic in organic synthesis. Additionally, N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC)-organocatalyzed multicomponent fluorination and fluoroalkylation have emerged as a powerful strategy for accessing diverse fluorinated compounds. The minireview summarizes the construction of fluorine-containing compounds via NHC-organocatalyzed multicomponent reactions over the past 15 years. Key reaction types include: i) NHC-catalyzed electrophilic fluorination and trifluoromethylation; and ii) NHC-catalyzed radical fluoroalkylation and cooperative NHC / transition metal catalyzed radical fluoroalkylation. Perspectives and insights into recent advancements in the research field are also provided at the end of the review.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: High Throughput Experimentation as a Tool to Guide the Microwave Assisted Catalytic Amidation of Aryl Amines with Aryl Acids
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
We utilized DoE, HTE and microwave synthesis to develop a catalytic amidation protocol that follows the principles of green chemistry through use of catalysis to improve atom economy, biorenewable solvent, high substrate loadings and energy efficient microwave heating.
Abstract The formation of amides is one of the most essential transformations in the pharmaceutical industry, but most synthetic procedures include the use of stoichiometric poor atom economy reagents. These limitations are often compounded when condensing aryl amines with aryl acids due to their inherently low reactivity. To overcome such hurdles, we utilized high throughput experimentation to screen 640 different reaction conditions to find a suitable catalyst and solvent for benzamide formation. Based on those initial findings, we developed an efficient catalytic transformation of aryl amines with aryl acids into N‐arylbenzamides using a 15 mol % loading of 2,4‐bis(trifluoromethyl) phenyl boronic acid and trimethylamine N‐oxide in 2‐MeTHF under microwave conditions for 1 h in the presence of 3 Å molecular sieves. Our method shows that even sterically hindered amines and carboxylic acids can be converted to the corresponding N‐arylbenzamides, including previously reported unreactive aromatic and secondary amines, in good to excellent yields. This approach follows the principles of green chemistry through use of[1] catalysis to improve atom economy,[2] a biorenewable solvent (2‐MeTHF),[3] high substrate loadings (0.5 M), and[4] energy efficient microwave heating.
item.content:encoded:
We utilized DoE, HTE and microwave synthesis to develop a catalytic amidation protocol that follows the principles of green chemistry through use of catalysis to improve atom economy, biorenewable solvent, high substrate loadings and energy efficient microwave heating.


Abstract

The formation of amides is one of the most essential transformations in the pharmaceutical industry, but most synthetic procedures include the use of stoichiometric poor atom economy reagents. These limitations are often compounded when condensing aryl amines with aryl acids due to their inherently low reactivity. To overcome such hurdles, we utilized high throughput experimentation to screen 640 different reaction conditions to find a suitable catalyst and solvent for benzamide formation. Based on those initial findings, we developed an efficient catalytic transformation of aryl amines with aryl acids into N-arylbenzamides using a 15 mol % loading of 2,4-bis(trifluoromethyl) phenyl boronic acid and trimethylamine N-oxide in 2-MeTHF under microwave conditions for 1 h in the presence of 3 Å molecular sieves. Our method shows that even sterically hindered amines and carboxylic acids can be converted to the corresponding N-arylbenzamides, including previously reported unreactive aromatic and secondary amines, in good to excellent yields. This approach follows the principles of green chemistry through use of[1] catalysis to improve atom economy,[2] a biorenewable solvent (2-MeTHF),[3] high substrate loadings (0.5 M), and[4] energy efficient microwave heating.

item.dc:title: High Throughput Experimentation as a Tool to Guide the Microwave Assisted Catalytic Amidation of Aryl Amines with Aryl Acids

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: User‐friendly and Green Procedure for a Photoinduced Wohl‐Ziegler Reaction
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A facile and ecofriendly catalyst‐free allylic and benzylic bromination method using a stoichiometric amount of NBS under LEDs light irradiation is described. This method provides an alternative to the Wohl‐Ziegler procedure which is classically performed in the presence of a radical initiator in the banned solvent CCl4. The method is applicable to a wide range of substrates, is easily scalable and is carried out at room temperature under air atmosphere. No special equipment other than the LEDs lamp is needed.
Abstract A convenient Wohl‐Ziegler bromination protocol using NBS under visible light in standard laboratory glassware is described. The monobromination reaction is efficient and selective over a wide range of substrates. Unlike previous studies, we prove that the use of a photocatalyst is unnecessary. The proposed protocol is simple to implement and applicable at the gram scale. The reaction takes place in a few tens of minutes at room temperature and offers an alternative to the use of CCl4, which is conventionally used for Wohl‐Ziegler bromination. Alternative conditions of bromination by CBr4 in the presence of a photocatalyst have also been investigated.
item.content:encoded:
A facile and ecofriendly catalyst-free allylic and benzylic bromination method using a stoichiometric amount of NBS under LEDs light irradiation is described. This method provides an alternative to the Wohl-Ziegler procedure which is classically performed in the presence of a radical initiator in the banned solvent CCl4. The method is applicable to a wide range of substrates, is easily scalable and is carried out at room temperature under air atmosphere. No special equipment other than the LEDs lamp is needed.


Abstract

A convenient Wohl-Ziegler bromination protocol using NBS under visible light in standard laboratory glassware is described. The monobromination reaction is efficient and selective over a wide range of substrates. Unlike previous studies, we prove that the use of a photocatalyst is unnecessary. The proposed protocol is simple to implement and applicable at the gram scale. The reaction takes place in a few tens of minutes at room temperature and offers an alternative to the use of CCl4, which is conventionally used for Wohl-Ziegler bromination. Alternative conditions of bromination by CBr4 in the presence of a photocatalyst have also been investigated.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: O‐C Glycoside Rearrangement through Time‐Controlled Electrochemical Flow Strategy: Switching between Kinetics and Thermodynamics
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
We herein report time‐controlled O‐C glycoside rearrangement in flow‐electrochemical microreactors, focusing on kinetic and thermodynamic selectivity. The selective synthesis of phenolic O‐ and C‐glycosides has been explored using O‐C glycoside rearrangement. We investigated the time‐control of O‐C glycoside rearrangement using a flow microreactor, which allows for second‐scale reaction control. The electrochemical approach demonstrated that shortening the residence time leads to the selective synthesis of O‐glycosides, while longer times favor the formation of C‐glycosides. Kinetic studies revealed that substituents on the phenol ring affect the rate of O‐glycoside formation and its rearrangement to C‐glycosides. Finally, continuous flow synthesis was demonstrated, showcasing the scalability and utility of this method for producing bioactive substances.

The electrochemical approach demonstrated that shortening the residence time leads to the selective synthesis of O‐glycosides, while longer times favor the formation of C‐glycosides. Kinetic studies revealed that substituents on the phenol ring affect the rate of O‐glycoside formation and its rearrangement to C‐glycosides. Finally, continuous flow synthesis was demonstrated, showcasing the scalability and utility of this method for producing bioactive substances.

Finally, continuous flow synthesis was demonstrated, showcasing the scalability and utility of this method for producing bioactive substances.
